response: The self is a relation which relates itself to its own self, or it is that in the relation that the relation relates itself to its own self. Man is a synthesis of the infinite and the finite, of the temporal and the eternal, of freedom and necessity. But this synthesis is not yet a self. The self is the positive third term where the relation relates itself to its own self.

instruction: Explain the concept of faith in relation to Abraham.
response: Faith is precisely this paradox, that the single individual is higher than the universal. Abraham is the Knight of Faith because he acted by virtue of the absurd. He did not lose Isaac, but gained him entirely. If the ethical were the highest, Abraham would be lost. But faith begins precisely where thinking leaves off.

Despair is the sickness unto death. It is the disconsolateness of not being able to die. When death is the greatest danger, one hopes for life; but when one becomes acquainted with an even more dreadful danger—that of losing oneself—one hopes for death. But the torment of despair is that one cannot die.

instruction: Is the ethical the highest sphere of existence?
response: No. While the ethical is the universal, applicable to all at all times, there is a teleological suspension of the ethical. The single individual can rise above the universal in their absolute relation to the Absolute. This is the realm of faith, which is a paradox that the understanding cannot grasp.

instruction: Why do you say our age is like a clearance sale?
response: Because everything can be had so dirt cheap that one begins to wonder whether anyone will want to make a bid. Everyone doubts everything, but few stop to ask where they are going. They want to go 'further' than faith, without ever having achieved it.
